Award.AwardTitle: FORCE: Focus on Occupations, Recruiting, Community, and Engagement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is increasing retention rates of freshmen who declare a science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) major from less than 30% to over 60% and increasing the number of undergraduates (freshmen and transfer students) who complete a bachelor's degree in STEM at the university from a four-year mean of about 120 to about 180. The main thesis of the project is that a focus on STEM related career opportunities and the pathways to obtain them will be of particular benefit to those students not yet declaring their majors and entering freshmen who declare their intent to major in STEM fields but are at risk of dropping out of that major. The project is engaging faculty, upper classmen and alumni in efforts to interest students in and inform them about STEM careers.

Intellectual Merit: Activities include: (1) personal invitations to potential majors to consider a STEM degree path; (2) a learning community targeting pre-calculus students and centered around a new course introducing students to a breadth of STEM degree and career trajectories; (3) the growth of a residential learning community; (4) deliberate and pro-active horizontal and vertical networking of STEM majors (and alumni) through events, a portal to connect STEM majors to STEM jobs on campus, and web-based social networking tools; (5) building a cadre of student ambassadors who represent the STEM disciplines as peer tutors, recruiters, and emissaries at events; and (6) expanding participation in undergraduate research projects. These activities are based on gender equity, STEP and other funded work at the University of Oklahoma investigating effective mechanisms to increase retention and graduation rates in (STEM) majors and a recent on-campus survey to determine why students dropped out of STEM majors or did not consider them as an option as they entered the university. The interdisciplinary within STEM aspect of this project is enabling students who had not previously considered a STEM major and those who become uncertain about their decisions and options to seek an optimal match within STEM instead of (or at least before) leaving STEM altogether.

Broader Impact. The interdisciplinary approach underscores the power of cross-department partnership so that other institutions might consider such a unified approach. The literature suggests that the proposed activities will benefit all STEM majors: women in male-dominated fields, men in general, and other marginalized populations such as first-generation students.

Institution.Name: NORTHERN KENTUCKY UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION (DO NOT USE)
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NORTHERN KENTUCKY UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION INC

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project FORCE (focus on occupations, recruiting, community, and engagement) focused on building a coordinated effort across the science, technology, (pre-)engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines at Northern Kentucky University (NKU) including the departments of Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Computer Science, Mathematics & Statistics, and Physics & Geology. The project had two overarching goals: (A) to increase the retention rate of first time freshmen who declare a STEM major at NKU from under 30% to at least 60% and (B) to increase the number of undergraduates (freshmen and transfer students) who complete a bachelor’s degree in STEM at NKU from a four-year mean of about 120 to about 180 (a 50% increase).

The goals of the project have been achieved through various efforts addressing both recruitment and retention. A coordinated STEM-wide recruitment effort consists of a STEM-specific two-page flyer, a STEM Showcase information session, targeted mailings to students highlighting our programs and scholarship offerings, and NKU STEM representation at recruiting fairs. UR-STEM targets early career, at-risk students through a part-time summer research experience. The goal is to match students with existing research teams and both help them feel a part of the academic community and learn research techniques. The last two components involve the STEM Ambassadors, junior and senior STEM majors who serve as emissaries for the FORCE program, and who are the driving force behind both STEM-specific social activities and peer-led study sessions. The STEM Ambassadors also participate in our university-wide recruiting activities.

The achievements include: (1) 36% increase in the number of students enrolled in the STEM disciplines; (2) 100% increase in the number of STEM degrees conferred; and (3) 31% increase in the number of NKU first-time freshman declaring a STEM major. Additionally, retention rates have been drastically higher for those who participate in FORCE activities (~70% or greater over 4 years) compared to a statistically similar group of STEM majors at NKU (~25%).

Building a STEM community with academic and social footholds has had a far-reaching impact in part due to the development and empowerment of student leaders across the STEM disciplines. Although increasing the number of underrepresented students was not one of the project goals, there has been a 31% increase in the number of underrepresented students enrolled in STEM disciplines since Project FORCE began. This increase far exceeds what can be attributed to the S-STEM funded Project SOAR, also in progress at NKU which seeks to increase underrepresented students in STEM.

The results of the project have been shared externally in the form of 16 conference presentations, two publications, and an invited STEM Central webinar. The Project FORCE team has also met regularly with NKU personnel and shared results through presentations and annual reports, including publications by NKU’s Center for Integrative Natural Sciences and Mathematics (CINSAM) and the Kentucky Center for Mathematics.

Successful aspects of this project – the STEM Ambassadors, peer-led learning, and early undergraduate research program (UR-STEM) – are continuing through the sponsorship of NKU’s CINSAM and Learning Plus Center. 


Last Modified: 12/30/2016
Modified by: Bethany V Bowling

The project had two overarching goals: (A) to increase the retention rate of first time freshmen who declare a STEM major at NKU from under 30% to at least 60% and (B) to increase the number of undergraduates (freshmen and transfer students) who complete a bachelor?s degree in STEM at NKU from a four-year mean of about 120 to about 180 (a 50% increase). The goals of the project have been achieved through various efforts addressing both recruitment and retention. A coordinated STEM-wide recruitment effort consists of a STEM-specific two-page flyer, a STEM Showcase information session, targeted mailings to students highlighting our programs and scholarship offerings, and NKU STEM representation at recruiting fairs. Additionally, retention rates have been drastically higher for those who participate in FORCE activities (~70% or greater over 4 years) compared to a statistically similar group of STEM majors at NKU (~25%). Building a STEM community with academic and social footholds has had a far-reaching impact in part due to the development and empowerment of student leaders across the STEM disciplines. Although increasing the number of underrepresented students was not one of the project goals, there has been a 31% increase in the number of underrepresented students enrolled in STEM disciplines since Project FORCE began. This increase far exceeds what can be attributed to the S-STEM funded Project SOAR, also in progress at NKU which seeks to increase underrepresented students in STEM. The results of the project have been shared externally in the form of 16 conference presentations, two publications, and an invited STEM Central webinar. The Project FORCE team has also met regularly with NKU personnel and shared results through presentations and annual reports, including publications by NKU?s Center for Integrative Natural Sciences and Mathematics (CINSAM) and the Kentucky Center for Mathematics. Successful aspects of this project – the STEM Ambassadors, peer-led learning, and early undergraduate research program (UR-STEM) – are continuing through the sponsorship of NKU?s CINSAM and Learning Plus Center.
